_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Inspected and functionally tested Unit 6 Snappy Joe Valves

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
March 2022 the RMP was resubmitted due to the 5 year requirement. All sections were reviewed and updated. 

April 2017 RMP was resubmitted due to the 5 year requirement.  All sections were reviewed and updated.   

12/2/2015  Update RMP due to new emergency contact and updated dates in section 7.0.

2012 RMP UPDATE DUE TO ADDING 2ND ANHYDROUS AMMONIA SYSTEM TO A NEW ELECTRIC GENERATING UNIT

INTRODUCTION

In response to the requirements of Federal EPA, this Risk Management Plan has been developed for the Rogers Energy Complex (REC) located in Cliffside, NC.  REC is owned and operated by Duke Energy.  The RMP Resubmission includes information for the existing anhydrous ammonia injection systems on REC Units 5 and 6. The two systems are operated independently.   

PLANT AND PROCESS INFORMATION

REC uses an anhydrous ammonia system as a component supporting selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of the plant's boiler emissions.  Ammonia vapor (in the presence of the SCR catalyst) reduces NOx compounds to elemental nitrogen and water to reduce the total NOx effluent emitted from the plant.  The first system was installed on Unit #5 in 2002 and the second system was installed in 2012 on Unit 6. The two systems are similar, however they operate independently of one another. The anhydrous ammonia system is comprised of four storage tanks, two with a capacity of 45,000 gallons each, and two with capacity of 60,000 gallons each, along with feed pumps and vaporizing equipment.  The total quantity of ammonia exceeds threshold quantities which invoke the requirements of the Risk Management regulations.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION MEASURES

REC is committed to public safety, employee safety, continued reliable operation, and regulatory compliance.  Based on this commitment, the Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Risk Management Program.  A management system has been developed with clearly defined accountabilit

ioning.  The accident history for this existing use was reviewed for comparative purposes.  Within the past five years, REC has had no accidental releases that resulted in injuries or property damage.  The plant has maintained an excellent safety record throughout its operating history and has never had any major chemical release that could have had adverse effects on the public.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE

In the event that an ammonia release does occur, REC has an emergency response program that coordinates emergency response with the appropriate off-site agencies including the Rutherford and Cleveland County Emergency Planning and Management agencies and the Cliffside Fire Department. REC maintains a 24/7 emergency response team on-site with the appropriate number of members, training, and equipment to actively respond to and take action necessary to secure credible releases of ammonia that might occur.  Additionally, there are a number of emergency operations procedures in place which detail the appropriate emergency actions that would help mitigate the effects of releases.

MAINTAINING A SAFE OPERATION

Duke Energy and Rogers Energy Complex will continually work to safely manage the hazards of the ammonia system to protect the communities we serve and the employees, vendors and visitors at the station.  The Risk Management Program will be maintained to reduce the risk of accidental releases through training, procedures, equipment maintenance, and safe work practices.  Periodically, REC will audit the program, review the Process Hazard Analysis, coordinate with community emergency response organizations, and will update the program as needed to assure safe and efficient control and management of the anhydrous ammonia system.
